Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Extreme Rainfall in Urban Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this study, the impacts of urbanization on extreme rainfall and flooding will be examined through a combination of intercomparison studies of rainfall and flooding from a diverse sample of urban watersheds in the US and through modeling studies of extreme rainfall and flooding. The principal question that will be addressed in this study is: How does urbanization alter the regional hydroclimatology of extreme rainfall and flooding? Research will be organized around questions that address urbanization impacts on the climatology of extreme rainfall and questions that address urbanization impacts on flood response in urban watersheds. Questions that focus on urbanization and extreme rainfall are the following: How does urbanization alter the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall from flood-producing storm systems? What are the characteristic life cycles of storm systems that produce flash floods in urban regions? How do land - water boundaries and complex terrain interact with the urban environment to control the regional distribution of extreme rainfall? Questions that focus on urbanization and extreme flooding are the following: How does urbanization alter the population of storm systems that are responsible for extreme flooding? How does the pattern of urban development, along with the space-time structure of rainfall, determine the scale-dependent flood response of urban watersheds?

Intellectual merit:
The research is designed to provide a predictive understanding of the impacts of urbanization on extreme rainfall and flooding. Urban environments represent an especially interesting and important setting for examining spatial heterogeneities in hydrometeorological processes. Urban environments also present a challenging setting for characterizing regional climate change and the research will contribute to a broader understanding of nonstationarities in extreme rainfall and flooding.

Broader impacts:
This project, which is a collaborative effort of research groups from Princeton and Purdue, will train graduate students and provide the resources and infrastructure for undergraduate students to carry out independent research projects (through Senior Thesis, Junior Independent Project and summer internships). Furthermore, the research elements of the project will be integrated throughout the undergraduate curriculum in Civil and Environmental Engineering at Princeton and at Environmental Science and Engineering as well as Meteorology and Applied Climate/Climate Change curriculum at Purdue, building on initiatives in the area of the "urban environment". Results obtained from this research will be of significant and immediate interest, not only to hydrologists, climate scientists and atmospheric scientists but also to a wide range of end users, including emergency management offices, urban planning programs and flood forecasting offices. The research will be translated into training material, which will be targeted for developing the education and workforce needs of sustainable science researchers and educators. Work with the Indiana State Climate Service Team and Purdue's Land Use Team to develop and disseminate training and outreach material will be carried out.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urbanization is an emerging change across global landscapes. While urban areas cover relatively small areas, their influence on the environment is at an order of magnitude larger spatial scale. This impact on the regional processes is exerted primarily because of the concentration of human activities and infrastructure development in the urban areas, which causes changes in the anthropogenic emissions, heating, and resulting changes in the overlaying environment. Urban areas also have, in recent years, witnessed a propensity for extreme rains and flooding. The intriguing scientific question and the drivers for the outcome of this project have been to understand how the urban areas affect storm systems and rainfall processes in a manner that could lead to scenarios of extreme or heavy rain and flooding. 

The project successfully developed intercomparison studies of rainfall and flooding from a diverse sample of urban watersheds and cities in the US and beyond through observational and modeling studies of extreme rainfall and flooding. The project helped answer the question: How does urbanization alter the regional hydroclimatology of extreme rainfall and flooding? Following a collaborative research model with teams from Purdue University and Princeton, the project activities were organized around topics of urbanization impacts on the climatology of extreme rainfall and urbanization impacts on flood response in urban watersheds. Project activities that focused on urbanization and extreme rainfall involved understanding: How does urbanization alter the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall from flood-producing storm systems? What are the characteristic life cycles of storm systems that produce extreme rains in urban regions? How do urban-rural boundaries and terrain interact with the urban environment to control the regional distribution of extreme rainfall? Questions that focus on urbanization and extreme flooding are the following: How should urbanization effects be considered when designing extreme flood scenarios? How does the pattern of urban development, along with the space-time structure of rainfall, determine the scale-dependent flood response of urban watersheds?

Intellectual merit:

The contributed to development of a comprehensive, predictive understanding of the impacts of urbanization on extreme rainfall and flooding. In broader sense, the urban-rural environments represent an especially interesting and important setting for examining spatial heterogeneities in hydrometeorological processes and assessing how storms can be impacted as a result of heterogeneity. Urban environments also present a challenging setting for characterizing regional climate change and the research contributed to a broader understanding of nonstationarities and processes involved in extreme rainfall and flooding.

Broader impacts:

This project was developed as a collaborative effort of research groups from Princeton and Purdue and involved students and partners from different national and international groups. This environment provided graduate students, young researchers and graduate as well as undergraduate students the resources and infrastructure for carrying high impact research projects (through graduate dissertation, masters thesis, Independent Project and summer internships). Furthermore, the research elements of the project were integrated in courses and lectures to the undergraduate curriculum in Civil and Environmental Engineering at Princeton and at Environmental Science and Engineering as well as Meteorology and Applied Climate/Climate Change curriculum at Purdue, building on initiatives in the area of the "urban environment". Results obtained from this research were communicated to peer reviewed publications, conferences and workshops, and more broadly to media. There was significant and immediate interest, in the context of the urban hazards that evolved during the course of the project that caused urban flooding. The research was developed into training module, and used in workshops and schools for developing the education and workforce needs of sustainable science researchers and educators. Work with the Indiana State Climate Service Team and Purdue's Extension was achieved to develop and disseminate training and outreach material will be carried out related to urban extreme hazards and preparedness.
